I'm interested in exploring the limits of what ANNs
can do, so my next problem is going to be one that's
well suited for the normal computing paradigm, but not
well suited for an ANN.  This problem requires short
term memory, and use of what is stored there, so an
MLP can't do the job.  It must be some kind of
recurrent ANN.  The problem is to play the game of
concentration.  That's the card game where all the
cards are spread face down and each player gets to
turn over two cards.  If they are a pair he keeps them
and gets another turn.  Otherwise they go face down
again.  When humans play it its mainly a test of
memory, although if your memory is perfect there is
some strategy involved.  (see Sci. Am. Oct. 1991)

This is a game that's natural for a conventional
computer program, quite different from what ANNs
usually do.  But since a recurrent ANN, or an MLP with
a memory, is supposed to be a universal Turing
machine, its theoretically capable of playing it.  I
want to know if that's true in practice as well.

I've written some C code that handles the game
mechanics, assuming there are players that choose
which card to turn over.  Right now I have dummy
players that pick at random.  I'll be glad to make the
code available if someone else want to use it.  I
would very much like to see someone apply NEAT to this
game.   (I won't be using NEAT, primarily because I
only know C, not C++)
